discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Answer is Correct.

You cannot directly convert a basic exFAT disk to ReFS (Resilient File System) because they are different file systems. Converting file systems usually requires reformatting the disk, which would result in data loss. However, you can copy the data from the exFAT disk to another location, reformat the disk as ReFS, and then copy the data back.

questions.question_text:
You have a server named Server1 that runs Windows Server. The disks on Server1 are configured as shown in the following exhibit.

//IMG//


You need to convert volume E to ReFS. The solution must meet the following requirements:

• The data on volume E needs to be retained.
• Minimize administrative effort.

What should you do first?

choices.A: Back up the data on volume E.
choices.C: Convert Disk 2 to a dynamic disk.

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP
-

You have a disaggregated cluster deployment. The deployment contains a scale-out file server (SOFS) cluster that runs Windows Server and a compute cluster that has the Hyper-V role enabled.

You need to implement Storage Quality of Service (QoS). The solution must ensure that you can control the bandwidth usage between the SOFS cluster and the Hyper-V cluster.

Which cmdlet should you run on each cluster? To answer, drag the appropriate cmdlets to the correct clusters. Each cmdlet may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Correct

On the SOFS cluster:
New-StorageQosPolicy: This cmdlet is used to create a new Storage QoS policy that defines the minimum and maximum IOPS (Input/Output Operations Per Second) for storage.

On the Hyper-V cluster:
Set-VMHardDiskDrive: This cmdlet is used to configure the QoS policy for a virtual hard disk drive attached to a virtual machine.

You do not need to use the Set-VMSan cmdlet in this scenario, as it is used for configuring virtual SANs (Storage Area Networks) and is not directly related to Storage QoS.

BitLocker: C, D, E

Server3 contains a data disk named Disk1 that has Data Deduplication installed. Disk1 contains the files shown in the following table.

//IMG//


Server3 fails.

You need to recover the files on Disk1.

Which files can you recover if you attach Disk1 to Server1, and which files can you recover if you attach Disk1 to Server2? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

comments.content: Hmm, dedup is not forward compatible, so no sure the 2019 server would be able deal with the 2022 deduped data disk.

discussion.content:
The file extension is not specified randomly, but with a purpose, namely to highlight the type of files.
File3.sys implies from the start that it is a system file.

Server1:
 - File1.txt, File2.doc, File3.sys, and File4.bmp
Server2:
 - File1.txt and File3.sys only

File1.txt : is not deduplicated (size less than 32kb)
File3.sys : is not deduplicated (system file)

Data deduplication is supported only on the following:
 - Windows Server operating systems beginning with Windows Server 2012
 - NTFS data volumes
 - Cluster shared volume file system (CSVFS) supporting virtual desktop infrastructure (VDI) workloads beginning with Windows Server 2012 R2

Deduplication skips over the following files:
 - System-state files
 - Encrypted files
 - Files with extended attributes
 - Files whose size is less than 32 KB
 - Reparse points (that are not data deduplication reparse points)
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/windows/desktop/dedup/about-data-deduplication
minimum for dedup is size 32kb, File1.txt can be recovered on server2, because is not deduplicated
We need more answers to this

comments.content: Correct. option 1, all files (because of the already installed dedup feature) and option 2, file1 and file3.

discussion.content: Deduplication skips over system state files. The .sys extension is usually used for operating system files. So if they're trying to imply that File3.sys is a system file, that would be ignored by deduplication, so the answer would be Server 2: File1.txt and File3.sys?

questions.question_text:
You have a server named Server1 that runs Windows Server and contains a file share named Share1.

You need to prevent users from storing MP4 files in Share1. The solution must ensure that the users can store other types of files in the share.

What should you configure on Server1?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
File screens (D). 
File screens allow you to create rules that block specific file types from being saved in a particular folder or share.
